awd_titl_txt: Cooperative dynamics in ligand binding reactions at the solution/solid interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Many large molecules have several chemically reactive sites. Oftentimes these sites behave independently, with the chemical reactions occurring at one site having no effect on the others. This is not always the case, however. In some instances, the binding at one site can change the chemical reactivity of another. Cooperation between reactive sites plays an important role in problems ranging from biology to molecular electronics. However, investigating cooperativity is challenging, since many experimental methods have trouble distinguishing the reactive sites. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry and the Chemical, Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A programs in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Ursula Mazur, Bhaskar Chilukuri, and K. W. Hipps at Washington State University are exploring cooperative effects in the binding of small molecules on nearby sites in large chemical complexes using a high resolution imaging method. The discoveries could aid in the design of new materials, as well as have broad implications for advancing technologies related to sensing, catalysis, and optoelectronics. The project's findings are incorporated into undergraduate courses at Washington State University, providing modern research examples to highlight concepts in chemistry, materials science, and engineering. The research labs involved in the project also provide training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, including a number of female and minority students.

Working with their students, Professors Mazur, Chilukuri, and Hipps are synthesizing large, electron-rich molecules that consist of multiple fused porphyrin rings, and then depositing them on conducting substrates such as Au, graphite, and MoS2. The team then exposes the porphyrin multimers to small molecules (e.g. O2, CO, and NO) that react with the metal centers. By imaging the products with scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), they can directly observe of cooperative binding. Experimental observations are compared with molecular dynamics and density functional theory calculations to determine if communication occurs through the metal support or the intramolecular pi structure, as well as the extent to which intermolecular coupling occurs. Professors Mazur, Chilukuri, and Hipps are involved in undergraduate education and mentoring students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broader impacts: With NSF support, the PIs introduced graduate, undergraduate, and high school students to the excitement of research in scanning probe microscopy and surface chemistry. One graduate and one undergraduate student were trained in multi-scale molecular modeling codes.  Three postdocs also worked in part on these projects. These postdocs were given opportunities for training in grant writing, publication writing, and (one of them) undergraduate teaching.  Laboratory tours and demonstrations were performed for undergraduate and local high school students to showcase research and STEM career opportunities. BC is engaged with mentoring chemistry club at ILSTU which performs various STEM activities targeting undergraduates, high school students and little children at the local Discovery Museum.  UM speaks at the annual Cougar Undergraduate Research Experience that targets freshmen interested in STEM research and is a member of the Graduate Mentors Academy.

Publications, presentations, and products from this grant:

  • 7 publications
  • 1 PhD student completed degree
  • 1 new PhD students learned basics of tunneling microscopy
  • 3 postdoctoral fellows trained both in sceince and in career development
  • 2 Undergraduate students learned advanced lab methods
  • 2 High School interns were introduced to research
  • 6 national and international invited presentations (3 killed by covid)

Intellectual Merit: Cooperativity in chemical binding at surfaces is emerging as critically important for understanding and designing sensors, electrodes, spintronics, and catalysts (see references and discussion in the proposal introduction).  Many of these important potential applications involve thin films or single molecules supported on conductors.  Cooperativity in surface processes may be broadly defined as a non-additive behavior of adjacent sites on a surface; e.g.; the adsorption energy of a ligand at a particular site is different if an adjacent site is occupied.  In biological systems, it is possible to have cooperative enhancements of factors of 300 over binding to a single site.

Our studies focused on exploring - at the single molecule level - reaction cooperativity of conductor supported materials in general and those occurring at the technologically important solution-solid interface in particular.  Our work to date emphasizes the need for a complete and quantitative model for surface cooperativity that goes beyond simple isotherms such as the Hill and Temkin models. We have demonstrated that cooperativity in surface reactions can be quantitively studied by scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), but the real work of understanding the role of each possible contributing factor remains.

The most significant outcomes of this work were demonstrating on the single molecule level the following. (1) Experimentally demonstrated that axial ligand reactions of surface supported porphyrins could be cooperative, non-cooperative, or anti-cooperative depending upon the system; (2) Demonstrated that nearest neighbor distribution analysis could be used to conclusively demonstrate the existence of cooperativity in the surface binding process; (3)  Theoretically, through density functional theory (DFT) that cooperativity in adsorption energy could arise from either through space or through substrate interactions; (4) DFT theory combined with the use of large super-cells has the potential for predicting the energetics of cooperative binding and for distinguishing through space and through substrate interactions; (5) Estimates of thermodynamic quantities (like energy and entropy changes) associated with surface processes in solution could be obtained by combining single molecule measurements on systems in contact with solvent with solvent free DFT surface calculations; (6) Single molecule studies are much more sensitive to cooperativity than isotherm based determination.  

The results of our findings have important implications for chemical sensing/recognition, heterogeneous catalytic processes, any surface supported electronic or magnetic process where cooperativity may play a role, and the development of theoretical and experimental methods intended for measuring and understanding cooperative phenomena.

Image
  • STM images of CoOEP supported on HOPG reveal that 3-phenylthiophene reversibly binds to the porphyrin. Analysis of numbers of bound nearest neighbors reveals that the binding is cooperative - binding to a CoOEP adjacent to a bound molecule is more favorable than binding in an un-bound region.
